title: The "tank meta" doesn't exist
body:
As much as that line is going to get me downvoted by people who won't bother to read what I'm about to say.

The tank meta doesn't exist. How much changed from a few months ago to now that suddenly tanks are considered the new meta? The largest addition was the Cinderhulk, but the tank junglers getting a huge buff to their core item (and the addition of Bami's) isn't THAT big enough to suddenly make them the new meta. Laners don't directly benefit from it. At most, it made the tank junglers viable again.

From my personal experiences in game, it seems like an overreaction from the assassin meta getting broadsided by their elemental nemesis. The core element of assassins is they deal their damage in one big burst and get away before they face retaliation. Tanks specialize in dealing their damage out over a longer period of time, but are able to last considerably longer in battle, sometimes able to bounce back much faster from damage, and hold down the enemy long enough to deal that damage to them. 

If assassins can't kill their mark, their only option available to them is to get the hell out. Unless they have someone to help pin down the enemy or just generally protect them from the enemy, either through buffs or crowd control, they melt in the hot sun under direct and sustained fire. Tanks by and large have exactly what destroys assassins, and since tanks received a decent boost to their earlier game, it made them a lot more capable of taking on their nemesis and winning.

The punchline is this isn't exactly new. Tanks received a huge boost in their power back during Season 4 when the Quill Coat was introduced, and what would later be remade into the smite buff from the Gromp. The short life of the Quill Coat, however, along with the entirety of the old jungle item sets made its impact quiet, minimal and short-lived.

Tanks are not the new meta. Assassins are just losing their ground from the previous season, yet people insist on bringing four AD assassins to the game regardless of how counterproductive it actually is, and this is becoming all the more apparent the longer it goes on.

Its actually because assassins literally took over the game by the end of season 4, as most instant punishments to deal with their superior mobility were removed, and the fact that most of them lived through the mana regen nerfs, unlike mages. 

The champions that dealt with assassins, tanks, were deeply sunk in tier 3 (most of them), being outplayable, slow starters, and easily counterjungled by mobile junglers, not to mention the fact that any ADC could bring them down with a Bork and a LW very quickly.

When the Cinderhulk was released, their clear times were powered up a lot, not to mention being allowed to have easily the best jungling enchantment due to how lackluster the others seem to be. This item is so good, it reaches the top lane as well, since tank itemization is honestly quite bad, cost-wise, compared to other roles. Cinderhulk's bonus HP and its passive are amazing, and tankier comps are perfect to deal with champions that need a lot of CC dropped on them to be caught, like Zed, LeBlanc and Nidalee.

This is why tanks became so good. Soon we will get AP Kog'Maws, Vaynes everywhere, Brands and Gnars, who love to see all these Cinderhulks running around (unless Cinderhulk gets nerfed into oblivion and we go back to the assassin meta, which is a lot worse IMO).

Maybe the passive isn't better than Sunfire, but 25% of your HP is huge. That is what top laners with smite wanted, not the immolate passive, because no item could do such a good job at making them tanky.

But I still agree with your thread man, tank meta would be teamfights lasting half an hour, with Warwick and Olaf auto-attacking each other for ages (good old days xD). Asides from junglers (and maybe a few supports), no other role has much of an advantage for picking a tank rather than anything else.

Tanks were always the counter to assassins, just as assassins have always been the counter to strong carries.  A meta favoring one  of those three is established when one counter is buffed enough to be a viable threat OUTSIDE of their ability to counter their nemesis class.  

In Season 4, the way to stop Zed was to choose a tankier champ.  Keane proved this more recently when he played Urgot into Zed.  Urgot benefitted only from a small direct buff to his shield, Urgot did not benefit at all from the general and targeted buffs that brought back tanks.  And the only thing that changed for Zed was a small nerf to attack speed.  This tells us that Urgot would have been VERY LIKELY to do just as well against Zed last season as he did when Keane brought the zombie to life.

The reason Zed was strong was not his ability to delete squishies.  He still does that, and yet is not considered as strong.  He was strong because, once he was done deleting that squishy, he could do respectable damage to tanks or split push and either kill one person or play safe against two.  That's what he can't do anymore, and that is why assassins have fallen out of favor.  If you see a good Zed in the game, either your ADC or squishy mid, if you picked one, is still going to die.  After that, though, Zed can't contribute anything more.

Tanks, however, received numerous direct buffs, particularly in the jungle, that translated into them not only being the counter to assassins, but being able to contribute beyond shutting down those assassins.  Now a tank can split push without worrying too much about the threat to their life.  Now they can dish out quite a lot of damage with Cinderhulk and Gromp buff.  And yes, those two things are the lion's share of the difference.  Every other jungler CAN get Cinderhulk, but their contribution suffers because they need damage.  Every other jungler CAN get Gromp buff and stomp wards, but the Gromp buff benefits those tanks more than anyone else, and the ward stomping Raptor buff is just as useful on tanks as anyone else.  PERHAPS, if Krug buff was actually threatening to champions, other junglers could shine as well.

So yes, tanks are the new meta, because they got buffed to be useful beyond their capability to counter another class.  And they are already seeing their time in the sun fade into shadow as their counters, which have always been strong, see a resurgence.  Just as Season 2 was the time of the tanks and saw the rise of the "ADC Deathball" comps that dominated afterward, and just as Season 4 was a response to those carries getting out of control and needing assassins to take them down again, so we come full circle, and will again.

And I, for one, eagerly anticipate the day when the wet noodle fight is considered the epitome of excitement in this game.
